message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Modeling Public Mood and Emotion: Twitter Sentiment and Socio-Economic Phenomena
Paper Abstract: We perform a sentiment analysis of all tweets published on the microblogging platform Twitter in the second half of 2008. We use a psychometric instrument to extract six mood states (tension, depression, anger, vigor, fatigue, confusion) from the aggregated Twitter content and compute a six-dimensional mood vector for each day in the timeline. We compare our results to a record of popular events gathered from media and sources. We find that events in the social, political, cultural and economic sphere do have a significant, immediate and highly specific effect on the various dimensions of public mood. We speculate that large scale analyses of mood can provide a solid platform to model collective emotive trends in terms of their predictive value with regards to existing social as well as economic indicators.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the search results for "Microblogging":

## Definition

Microblogging is a form of blogging using short posts without titles known as microposts or status updates.(no content)Microblogs allow users to exchange small elements of content such as short sentences, individual images, or video links.

## Popular Services

Notable microblogging services include Twitter, Tumblr, Mastodon, Micro.blog, FriendFeed, Plurk, Jaiku and identi.ca.(no content)Other social networking websites such as Facebook, MySpace, LinkedIn, Diaspora, JudgIt and XING also have their own microblogging feature, better known as "status updates".

## Regional Variations

In China, microblogging takes a different form. Weibo is a Chinese-based mini-blogging service that makes it possible for internet users to set up real-time information sharing communities individually and upload and update information.(no content)Weibo services use a format similar to the American-based Twitter service but are used almost exclusively by Chinese language speakers.

## Character Limits

Posts typically contain short text, usually 280 characters or less.

## Overview

Twitter, Inc. was an American social media company based in San Francisco, California, which operated and was named for its flagship social media network prior to its rebrand as X.(no content)It is one of the world's largest social media platforms and one of the most-visited websites.

## Core Features

Users could share concise text messages, images, and videos through "tweets" and engage with other users' content via likes or "retweets".(no content)The platform also includes direct messaging, video, and Twitter Spaces is a social audio feature that enables users to host or participate in a live-audio virtual environment called space for conversation.

## Company History and Ownership Changes

Twitter, Inc. was merged with X Corp. in April 2023.(no content)Twitter was an American social networking service that was rebranded as X in 2023.(no content)As of December 2025, Elon Musk, businessman and owner of the website, has the most-followed account with over 229 million followers.

## User Base and Growth

By the start of 2019, Twitter had more than 330 million monthly active users.(no content)Twitter then experienced considerable growth during the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020.

Web search results for query: "Sentiment analysis"

Links: [{"title":"Multimodal sentiment analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multimodal_sentiment_analysis"},{"title":"Sentiment analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sentiment_analysis"},{"title":"Market sentiment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Market_sentiment"},{"title":"General Sentiment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Sentiment"},{"title":"Lexalytics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lexalytics"},{"title":"MeaningCloud - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MeaningCloud"},{"title":"News analytics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/News_analytics"},{"title":"Text mining - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Text_mining"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Wikipedia Signpost/2013-04-29/Recent research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Wikipedia_Signpost/2013-04-29/Recent_research"},{"title":"Topsy Labs - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topsy_(analytics)"}]

## Sentiment Analysis - Overview

Sentiment analysis (also known as opinion mining or emotion AI) is the use of natural language processing, text analysis, computational linguistics, and biometrics to systematically identify, extract, quantify, and study affective states and subjective information.

### Applications

Sentiment analysis is widely applied to voice of the customer materials such as reviews and survey responses, online and social media, and healthcare materials for applications that range from marketing to customer service to clinical medicine.

### Basic Tasks

A basic task in sentiment analysis is classifying the polarity of a given text at the document, sentence, or feature/aspect level—whether the expressed opinion in a document, a sentence or an entity feature/aspect is positive, negative, or neutral.(no content)There are various other types of sentiment analysis, such as aspect-based sentiment analysis, grading sentiment analysis (positive, negative, neutral), multilingual sentiment analysis and detection of emotions.

### Advanced Approaches

With the rise of deep language models, such as RoBERTa, also more difficult data domains can be analyzed, e.g., news texts where authors typically express their opinion/sentiment less explicitly.

### Multimodal Sentiment Analysis

Multimodal sentiment analysis is a technology for traditional text-based sentiment analysis, which includes modalities such as audio and visual data.(no content)Similar to the traditional sentiment analysis, one of the most basic task in multimodal sentiment analysis is sentiment classification, which classifies different sentiments into categories such as positive, negative, or neutral.

Links: [{"title":"Psychometrics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychometrics"},{"title":"Psychometric Entrance Test - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychometric_Entrance_Test"},{"title":"Psychometry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychometry"},{"title":"Computational psychometrics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_psychometrics"},{"title":"Category:Psychometrics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Psychometrics"},{"title":"Psychometric software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychometric_software"},{"title":"Psychometry (paranormal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychometry_(paranormal)"},{"title":"Talk:Psychometrics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Psychometrics"},{"title":"Psychrometrics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychrometrics"},{"title":"Psychometrika - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychometrika"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about psychometry and psychometric testing:

## Psychometrics Overview

Psychometrics is a field of study within psychology concerned with the theory and technique of measurement, covering specialized fields within psychology and education devoted to testing, measurement, assessment, and related activities.(no content)Psychometrics is concerned with the objective measurement of latent constructs that cannot be directly observed.(no content)Examples of latent constructs include intelligence, personality factors (e.g., introversion), mental disorders, and educational achievement.

## How It Works

The levels of individuals on nonobservable latent variables are inferred through mathematical modeling based on what is observed from individuals' responses to items on tests and scales.

## Practitioners

Practitioners are described as psychometricians, although not all who engage in psychometric research go by this title. Most psychometricians are psychologists with advanced graduate training in psychometrics and measurement theory.

## Key Distinction

It's worth noting that in parapsychology, psychometry is a form of extrasensory perception characterized by the purported ability to glean accurate knowledge of an object's history by making physical contact with that object, though there is no evidence that psychometry exists, and the concept has been widely criticized. This is separate from the scientific field of psychometrics discussed above.

Web search results for query: "Socioeconomic indicator economics"

Links: [{"title":"Economic indicator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_indicator"},{"title":"Socioeconomic status - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socioeconomic_status"},{"title":"Economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socioeconomic_development"},{"title":"Social Progress Index - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Progress_Index"},{"title":"Global Social Mobility Index - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_Social_Mobility_Index"},{"title":"OECD Better Life Index - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OECD_Better_Life_Index"},{"title":"Economic sociology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socioeconomics"},{"title":"Income inequality metrics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Income_inequality_metrics"},{"title":"Social inequality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_inequality"},{"title":"Social economy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_economy"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about socioeconomic indicators in economics:

## Definition and Scope

Socioeconomic status (SES) is a measurement used by economists and sociologists that combines a person's or their family's economic or wealth level and social position (generally determined by education level) in relation to others.

## Key Components

When placing a family or individual into one of these categories, any or all of the three variables (income, education, and occupation) can be assessed. Additionally, research has revealed a lesser-recognized attribute of SES as perceived financial stress, as it defines the "balance between income and necessary expenses".

## Classification Levels

Socioeconomic status is typically broken into three levels (high, middle, and low) to describe the three places a family or an individual may fall into.

## Socioeconomics as a Field

Socioeconomics deals with the analytical, political and moral questions arising at the intersection between economy and society from a broad interdisciplinary perspective with links beyond sociology to political economy, moral philosophy, institutional economics and history.

## Health and Well-being Implications

Socioeconomic status has long been related to health, those higher in the social hierarchy typically enjoy better health than those below, and socioeconomic status is an important source of health inequity, as there is a very robust positive correlation between socioeconomic status and health.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Mood emotion psychology"

Links: [{"title":"Mood (psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mood_(psychology)"},{"title":"Emotion classification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotion_classification"},{"title":"Emotion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotion"},{"title":"Affect (psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affect_(psychology)"},{"title":"Affect measures - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affect_measures"},{"title":"Wikipedia:WikiProject Psychology/Emotion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Psychology/Emotion"},{"title":"Mood management theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mood_management_theory"},{"title":"Mood-dependent memory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mood-dependent_memory"},{"title":"Dispositional affect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dispositional_affect"},{"title":"Affective neuroscience - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affective_neuroscience"}]

I've performed a web search on "Mood emotion psychology" and found comprehensive information. Here are the key findings:

## Key Definitions

Emotions are physical and mental states brought on by neurophysiological changes, variously associated with thoughts, feelings, behavioral responses, and a degree of pleasure or displeasure. In contrast, moods are enduring affective states that are considered less intense than emotions and appear to lack a contextual stimulus.

## Differences Between Mood and Emotion

An emotion tends to have a clear focus (i.e., its cause is self-evident), while mood tends to be more unfocused and diffuse. Additionally, mood is viewed as more persistent and less intense than emotional state, and as a result more stable.

## Broader Concepts

Affect, in psychology, is the underlying experience of feeling, emotion, attachment, or mood, and encompasses a wide range of emotional states that can be positive (e.g., happiness, joy, excitement) or negative (e.g., sadness, anger, fear, disgust).

## Emotional Classification

A popular example is Paul Ekman and his colleagues' cross-cultural study of 1992, in which they concluded that the six basic emotions are anger, disgust, fear, happiness, sadness, and surprise.(no content)The PAD emotional state model is a psychological model developed by Albert Mehrabian and James A. Russell to describe and measure emotional states using three dimensions: Pleasure, Arousal and Dominance.

## Neurobiological Basis

Affective neuroscience is the study of how the brain processes emotions, combining neuroscience with the psychological study of personality, emotion, and mood.

message_text:
Perfect! All tasks have been completed successfully. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

I've successfully analyzed the paper "Modeling Public Mood and Emotion: Twitter Sentiment and Socio-Economic Phenomena" and created a comprehensive triples output.

**Paper Classification:** **Contribution** - The paper proposes a novel six-dimensional mood vector framework and methodology for analyzing collective public mood through social media.

**Key Triples Identified:**

1. **Twitter** (tool) - Primary data source for collecting tweets
2. **Sentiment analysis** (method) - Core analytical technique for extracting mood information
3. **Psychometrics** (method) - Used to extract and measure mood dimensions
4. **Mood (psychology)** (concept) - The novel framework proposed for collective public mood
5. **Microblogging** (tool) - The platform infrastructure leveraged
6. **Socioeconomic status** (concept) - Existing indicators being predicted from mood trends

**Validation Status:** ✅ **PASSED**

The triples_output.json file has been updated with all six triples, each with:
- Correct Wikipedia article titles
- Appropriate entity types (2 tools, 2 methods, 2 concepts)
- Valid relation types (4 uses, 1 proposes)
- Proper Wikipedia URLs
- Relevant explanations

All validation checks passed successfully!

Sources:
- [Twitter - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter)
- [Sentiment analysis - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sentiment_analysis)
- [Psychometrics - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychometrics)
- [Mood (psychology) - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mood_(psychology))
- [Microblogging - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microblogging)
- [Socioeconomic status - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socioeconomic_status)
